question: What process affects a rock when water flows over it for many years?

content.source_1: Flowing water mechanically abrades rock surfaces: repeated impacts and scraping by entrained sediment round and smooth rocks over long periods while removing material.
content.source_2: Water chemically weathers rocks by dissolving soluble minerals (such as calcite), gradually reducing the rock’s mass and size over time.
content.source_3: In carbonate‑rich, supersaturated waters (common at karst springs), turbulence and CO2 degassing trigger calcite precipitation onto any surface in the flow.
content.source_4: At travertine/tufa‑forming streams and waterfalls, measured carbonate deposition rates can exceed concurrent mechanical erosion, so rocks and ledges grow outward as successive mineral layers accumulate.
content.source_5: A stream’s abrasive power increases with velocity and sediment load, enhancing the rounding and wear of rocks lying in the channel.
content.source_6: Hard water repeatedly flowing over a surface can leave mineral scale that thickens into a crust when the supply of dissolved minerals is continuous.
